title: UK Joblessness Rises to Highest in Almost Five Years
summary: In the UK, more people are without jobs than in nearly five years, with the unemployment rate reaching 5.2% at the end of 2025. Young people aged 16 to 24 are especially affected, with 16.1% of them unemployed, the highest since 2020. The government says it is working to help by creating apprenticeships, but some politicians blame tax increases for making it harder for businesses to hire. A young graduate named Lucy is struggling to find a job in publishing because entry-level roles are very competitive and require experience she doesn't have. This situation is part of a broader economic slowdown where companies are hiring less due to higher costs.

background_read: Unemployment means people who are able and looking for work cannot find jobs. In the UK, this is measured by the Office for National Statistics (ONS), which collects data on employment. Young people often face higher unemployment because they may lack experience or skills. Governments try to reduce unemployment by creating programs like apprenticeships, where people learn on the job. Businesses hire based on their needs and costs; if costs rise, they might hire fewer people. This article discusses how unemployment has increased recently, especially for young adults, and what different groups are doing about it.
Article_Structure: WHO: Young people aged 16-24, the government, businesses, and a graduate named Lucy.
WHAT: Unemployment in the UK rose to 5.2%, with young people most affected at 16.1%.
WHY: Because of higher costs for businesses, tax increases, and a competitive job market for entry-level roles.

perspectives.description: The government is creating apprenticeships to help young people find jobs and says tackling youth unemployment is a priority.
Some politicians blame tax hikes for making hiring expensive and causing job losses, especially for young people.
A graduate like Lucy finds it hard to get entry-level jobs because they are competitive and require experience she lacks.
